content: President Obama does not get to decide to not release the photos. There is a Court order that the photos must be released, under the Freedom of Information Act. The court case has gone on for more than four years. Every angle the Bush Administration tried, including that the release of the photos would cause outrage in the Muslim world, has been shot down by the courts. Maybe President Obama has better lawyers than President Bush and can come up with better legal arguments to not release the photos. However, ultimately it is up to the Courts to decide if the photos get released. By at least trying, CinC Obama shows his concern for the troops in the field by trying to appeal the Court’s decision.
reply: President Obama does not get to decide to not release the photos. There is a Court order that the photos must be released, under the Freedom of Information Act. content: EITs aren't troture. Waterboarding isn't torture, and I'm tired of hearing the left say that we hung Japanese for waterboarding in WWII. What the Japanese were prosecuted for is called Water Cure, and it involved forcing POWs to drink water to the point where it was toxic, and caused death, which by definition, is torture. When American lives are at risk, personally, I go back to W.W.J.B.D. (What Would Jack Bauer Do). We did not "torture" detainees, period.

I can see why military commanders would not want the pictures to see the light of day though, of course, it shows the American (good guy) military brutalizing and otherwise sexually humiliating people and makes us look bad so damage control and censorship are in order, but they say it's because it will "harm" the troops, ya OK... Maybe their reputations will be hurt, but that's about it. They can fight back, right? I mean if some Haj wants to go crazy over the pics, let him, maybe we'll get a better chance of wacking him out before he gets to. Maybe not, ether way it's war, and we're in it, so let's fight it, or get the **** out!!

I believe that, as stated in the released "torture" memos, that an open hand slap, with detailed instructions on the execution, was the extent of the "beating".

content: President Obama does not get to decide to not release the photos. There is a Court order that the photos must be released, under the Freedom of Information Act. The court case has gone on for more than four years. Every angle the Bush Administration tried, including that the release of the photos would cause outrage in the Muslim world, has been shot down by the courts. Maybe President Obama has better lawyers than President Bush and can come up with better legal arguments to not release the photos. However, ultimately it is up to the Courts to decide if the photos get released. By at least trying, CinC Obama shows his concern for the troops in the field by trying to appeal the Court’s decision.
reply: President Obama does not get to decide to not release the photos. There is a Court order that the photos must be released, under the Freedom of Information Act. content: EITs aren't troture. Waterboarding isn't torture, and I'm tired of hearing the left say that we hung Japanese for waterboarding in WWII. What the Japanese were prosecuted for is called Water Cure, and it involved forcing POWs to drink water to the point where it was toxic, and caused death, which by definition, is torture. When American lives are at risk, personally, I go back to W.W.J.B.D. (What Would Jack Bauer Do). We did not "torture" detainees, period.

content: Our troops are in harm's way because we (Bush) put them there and because we (Obama) refuse to get them out of it, so as for all this talk about these pictures putting them in harm's way, I don't buy it. They're already there! In harm's way that is. I can see why military commanders would not want the pictures to see the light of day though, of course, it shows the American (good guy) military brutalizing and otherwise sexually humiliating people and makes us look bad so damage control and censorship are in order, but they say it's because it will "harm" the troops, ya OK... Maybe their reputations will be hurt, but that's about it. They can fight back, right? I mean if some Haj wants to go crazy over the pics, let him, maybe we'll get a better chance of wacking him out before he gets to. Maybe not, ether way it's war, and we're in it, so let's fight it, or get the **** out!!

That makes our actions as a nation illegal, period. Honestly, I really don't care if the "world" courts agree with me or not. They don't have the best interests of the US, our country, at heart. So, what you're saying is that you're willing to sacrifice the lives of US citizens in order to satisfy "world" opinion. I believe that there's proof that these IETs worked, and I believe that it's contained in the memos that former Vice President Cheney asked to be released, and the proof that it is contained in the memos is the fact that the Obama administration has refused to release them. I put the safety of our citizens first, to hell with the rest of the "world".
quote: Originally posted by SeaWitch1220: quote: Originally posted by psychoABN: EITs aren't troture. Waterboarding isn't torture, and I'm tired of hearing the left say that we hung Japanese for waterboarding in WWII. What the Japanese were prosecuted for is called Water Cure, and it involved forcing POWs to drink water to the point where it was toxic, and caused death, which by definition, is torture. When American lives are at risk, personally, I go back to W.W.J.B.D. (What Would Jack Bauer Do). We did not "torture" detainees, period. Well, most world courts, including our own, disagree with your definition of torture. The President of the United States has declared that waterboarding IS torture. John McCain, who himself was tortured, has declared that waterboarding is torture. What we did was illegal. We are not only signors of the Geneva Conventions, but also the Conventions on Torture. That makes our actions as a nation illegal, period.
reply: Honestly, I really don't care if the "world" courts agree with me or not. They don't have the best interests of the US, our country, at heart. So, what you're saying is that you're willing to sacrifice the lives of US citizens in order to satisfy "world" opinion. I believe that there's proof that these IETs worked, and I believe that it's contained in the memos that former Vice President Cheney asked to be released, and the proof that it is contained in the memos is the fact that the Obama administration has refused to release them. I put the safety of our citizens first, to hell with the rest of the "world".
title: President Obama decides not to release interrogation photos
